stix:STIX_Header.stix:Title: HTTP GET Request Leads to Emotet
stix:STIX_Header.stix:Description:
On November 21, 2017, a trusted third party observed suspicious HTTP GET request to "www.reinfotechpride.com", which resulted in the download of a malicious word document "Invoice #5757798" [MD5: 1d39850ca60c50e640ee754d1a135c8d], which was detected as Emotet malware.
According to another trusted third party, Emotet is a modular credential theft Trojan that primarily collects usernames and passwords for accounts at financial institutions. The malware downloads and executes various modules from hard-coded command and control (C&C) servers. The modules are not written to disk but loaded directly from memory and include web browser and email client credential harvesters, an email scraper for Microsoft Outlook, and a spam engine.
This activity was observed in the Healthcare and Public Health sector.

marking:Marking_Structure.TOUMarking:Terms_Of_Use: DISCLAIMER: This report is provided "as is" for informational purposes only. Recipients may only use TLP:AMBER information with members of their own organization, and with clients or customers who need to know the information to protect themselves or prevent further harm. For more information on the Traffic Light Protocol, see http://www.us-cert.gov/tlp.

stix:Indicator.indicator:Title: Malicious FQDN Indicator
stix:Indicator.indicator:Description:
According to the trusted third party, a suspicious HTTP GET request to domain "www.reinfotechpride.com" resulted in the download of the malicious word document "Invoice #5757798" [MD5: 1d39850ca60c50e640ee754d1a135c8d].
DNS records indicate the domain resolves to IP "23.229.206.200" and host URLs detected as malicious.

stix:Indicator.indicator:Title: Malicious File Indicator
stix:Indicator.indicator:Description:
According to the trusted third party, HTTP GET request from a Healthcare and Public Health host to domain "www.reinfotechpride.com" resulted in the download of the malicious word document "Invoice #5757798" [MD5: 1d39850ca60c50e640ee754d1a135c8d], which was detected as Emotet malware.
According to open-source research, [MD5: 1d39850ca60c50e640ee754d1a135c8d] has been observed with additional filenames:
Invoice #1480245.doc SW-EBFA (21 Nov 17).doc Invoice #528517111.doc Invoice #1138748223.doc RC-QEA (21 Nov 17).doc KZA-CKI (21 Nov 17).doc Invoice #708690654.doc DHL Express - Dienstag, 14:00-18:00 Uhr.doc Invoice #9012804.doc Invoice #7962952058.doc Invoice #253409796850.doc Invoice #111445949129.doc Invoice #865760486728.doc Invoice #4945802131.doc 71b723eed5f4f076d5f9374d5e28cda2250b82c37ccd9e9b4f6bcb00973c3dd3.doc.000 Invoice #9624411.doc Invoice #905080574.doc Invoice #2886203052.doc Invoice #9402691947.doc Invoice #3572860152.doc Invoice #272393613867.doc Invoice #9726038602.doc Invoice #74148594885.doc GB-PVTDP (21 Nov 17).doc Invoice #33530289.doc

stix:Indicator.indicator:Title: Malicious FQDN Indicator
stix:Indicator.indicator:Description:
According to the trusted third party, the malware "Invoice #5757798" [MD5: 1d39850ca60c50e640ee754d1a135c8d] calls back to the domain "www.yourflyness.com".
DNS records indicate the domain resolves to IP "108.179.242.143" and host URLs detected as malicious.
